So of course I think these forsworn guys plan on overthrowing the Silver Bloods or something. I'm just worried that maybe if I go through with this, I end up missing out on quests from the other side. Not to mention I remember clearing a forsworn fort on the way to the city.](/spoiler) So is it safe to assume that everyone who is automatically hostile to you is safe to kill without consequences of missing out on quest lines?

It's hard to explain depression but what I have is like a higher threshold for pleasure. Things that make me really happy still make me really happy but things that are supposed to make me regular happy don't make me happy anymore and that results in a lack of motivation to do anything. I don't feel pleasure from watching mediocre TV shows or playing most video games anymore. Imagine looking at a massive list of TV shows or games and going "there's nothing good to play or watch" but apply that to every activity in life. Eventually, it gets to the point that you don't even wanna leave the bed anymore. Different people react to that kind of experience differently though. Some are strong enough to pull out of it and stay ahead, others realize they have a problem and seek out help, others... don't.

95% of the time, it's the cable that breaks while the actual drivers/earbuds work fine. I'm into electronics so I know how to solder. That let me justify buying expensive earphones cause I can just re-cable them each time they break. I used to have a Sony pair that lasted 4 years but went through over 10 cables/jacks until the actual earbuds fell into water. For most people though, a long warranty will do. It makes sense for manufacturers because they can just recable the ones you send in easily.

I heard they actually do ask some questions. The one I remember was "Did you let anyone else use your headphones?" and you should say that you're the only one who uses them because it's a personal warranty and lending it to people voids that.

You can get either Zinc Air or Alkaline cells. The Zinc Air cells have a defined life span whether you use it or not but maintain a steady voltage throughout. The Alkalines start off at a higher voltage then tapers down. It can start off overexposing, then perfect, then underexposing (or I think it's backwards?) and it can be a whole stop off. Shouldn't be too bad if you're shooting negatives. I'd rather not deal with that though so I just go manually.
Yeah! It's coming back now! Thanks!

WRITING.TEXT: Hey /r/askelectronics! I'm trying to design a board for a guitar effects pedal. It's got TRS connectors, potentiometers and a DPDT switch but since they won't be mounted on the board itself, I was wondering how I could plot their pins separately. Here's what I'm working on. http://i.imgur.com/xVrz8eE.png Basically, I want to turn all the objects on the left into holes around the board that I can just wire the actual components to but I'm not sure how to do that in Eagle.

WRITING.TITLE: If a ceramic disc capacitor is labeled "220" is that a 22pf or a 220pf capacitor?
WRITING.TEXT: Sorry if it's a dumb question but every value chart online has told me that "22 or 220" is 22pf while "221" is 220pf and yet 4 different branches of 2 different stores have tried to sell me a "220" capacitor when I asked for a 220pf capacitor. When I specifically ask for a "221" capacitor, they either say they don't have any or that it's the same thing as a "220".
Building a guitar effects pedal. This one http://www.muzique.com/schem/shaka5.htm

Actually, they're all electronics parts stores and sell all kinds of DIY components and kits which is why I sort of trust them. I've never had a problem with the parts they provided until my current project (a guitar effects pedal) would cut off after a few seconds and I suspected my caps were too small. Strangely enough, the problem only occured on the protoboard. When I applied it to a PCB, it works okay, leading me to believe the parts are fine and long component legs on a protoboard just messed with the signal too much.

WRITING.TITLE: The dreaded first activity of any team building event. Especially with people you've just met.

WRITING.TEXT: Start a journal. Physical traits like voice and looks are easily saved in audio and photo/video but it's your personality that's most important. Unfortunately, there's no cookie cutter method for backing this up right now like taking a 3D scan of yourself or recording yourself reciting the phonetic equivalent of "The quick brown fox". Any kind of objective "personality test" will have finite outcomes and even if it manages to nail down your general personality, it's the nuances that make us unique. The best way to preserve this is to provide whoever is trying to reconstruct you (when the technology becomes available) with as many viable data points as possible. Who we are is the result of every experience and memory we have and our individuality is expressed in how we each react to new stimuli using this knowledge. You'll want to save as many memories as you can for someone to rebuild you accurately.

According to Machiavelli, every endeavor is a dichotomy of fortuna and virtu. Fortuna is the circumstance we live in. The environment we were born into. The things the universe throws at us that we have no control over. Virtu is our own personal strengths and will. Our ability to overcome obstacles. Our own actions and everything we can control. I realized that as long as I give 100% of myself, I can die happy knowing I tried. Failure is only in giving up.

Ran into an old classmate.
WRITING.TEXT: My name is Alice, and i was sitting in the waiting room for my first appointment with a new dentist. I noticed his DDS diploma on the wall, which bore his full name. Suddenly, I remembered a tall, handsome, dark-haired boy with the same name had been in my high school class some 30-odd years ago. Could he be the same guy that i had a secret crush on, way back then? Upon seeing him, however, I quickly discarded any such thought. This balding, gray-haired man with the deeply lined face was way too old to have been my classmate. After he examined my teeth, i asked him if he had attended Morgan Park High school . 'Yes. Yes, i did. I'm a mustang,' he gleamed with pride. When did you graduate?' i asked. He answered, 'in 1985. Why do you ask?' 'You were in my class!', I exclaimed. He looked at me closely. Then, that ugly, old, bald, wrinkled faced, fat-assed, gray-haired, decrepit son-of-a-bitch asked, What did you teach???

WRITING.TITLE: My heart goes out to everyone in France.
Sister stole my blanket.
WRITING.TEXT: My sister and I share a room with opposite beds. I'm the kind of person that gets cold easily while she tends to feel too warm. As a result, the thermostat of the AC is set to her favorite setting while I use a thin blanket. I started feeling a bit chilly recently so I dug out this old thick blanket we had at home. I even had to dust and wash it before I could use it. I had the best night of sleep after that, all comfy like a big toasty cinnamon bun. This happened over the weekend so I even got to sleep in. Now, my sister usually gets in bed earlier than me. The next evening, I notice she's taken MY blanket and is already wrapped up and asleep on her bed. I didn't want to take it from her cause she gets cranky if you try to wake her, but mostly because she's the kind of sweetheart who could get away with murder. But no way was she getting away with stealing my awesome blanket like a petty thief. So I pulled out the knob of the thermostat, reseated it a few notches down then raised the temperature back to "her setting". By morning, she had ditched the blanket and I was able to steal it back and recalibrate the thermostat.

If I were in your shoes, I'd create a second version of the program with all the variable, function, object, and file names changed, replace all client assets with generic information and release it under an open source license. You can publish it in Github and maintain sole authorship. It will essentially be a new program based on the same logic and you can continue development there as well as use it to demonstrate your skills to prospective employers. Something like how Drupal, or OpenCMS, or ResourceSpace is published.

You're weak now. But you can be stronger in the future. Our bodies and minds are pliable. Routinely engaging in activites makes us better at those activities, and that is true both mentally and physically. In my case, I get anxious when I feel unprepared. To get over it, I started preparing myself. I work out to get stronger because physical power is useful. I practice situational awareness to keep mindful of whats going on. For example, crowded areas make me feel uneasy and being caught in a stampede or fire or collapsing building is one of my biggest fears. To keep on top of that, I always pay attention to where fire exits are, where possible fire risks might begin, and I choose to position myself in a crowd such that I have a clear escape path at any given moment. This allows me to get over my fears and I am able to enjoy one of my "incompatible" hobbies which is watching live music. If you feel that you are limited by something, remember that with enough time, effort, and determination, we are able to raise our limits. We are able to equip ourselves, physically, mentally, and materially for any situation. Join a gym. Train yourself to run long distances. Take a self defense class. See a counselor about controlling and understanding your anxiety. Evaluate your home's entry points and security. Dry run a household fire/earthquake drill. Pack a bug out bag. Have all your important documents in a waterproof envelope ready for a grab and go. Get first aid certified. Build a bunker in your basement and stock it with supplies. Become a practical doomsday prepper because a zombie apocalypse is the best worst-case scenario and if you are prepared for that, you're prepared for home invaders, neighborhood riots, crazy weather, economic collapse. Of course, those examples got extreme but it's up to you to decide what level of preparedness is enough to give you the peace of mind you need which is the opposite of anxiety and helplessness.

Fitness apps that don't need the phone nearby?
WRITING.TEXT: Hey everyone, so I've used fitness apps in the past to track my activity but I didn't like bringing my phone with me for a jog or to the gym. I was wondering what watch apps work great without having the iPhone. Quite a few times have a left the house wanting to try a new app with just my watch only to be greeted by a screen telling me to start an activity in the phone first. I'm currently trying out Gym Log+ and Gymaholic and I'm looking for a great C25k app.

My biggest need right now is a C25k app or interval trainer app. All the ones in the app store that I've tried so far require the user to start the run on the iPhone and the watch just acts as a monitor. Even if I start the run on my phone then leave it at home (or turn off bluetooth) the watch app then stops working.

lol kindness. Data integrity is one of their big selling points. 80% of their profits come from 20% of their clients which are businesses. Holding on to 1TB of data that doesn't change is inconsequential for a platform that operates in the exabyte range. Even the $9.99 I give them once is nothing compared to their $1 Billion annual revenue. The utility I derive from such a low cost both to myself and the company is immense. Even if I actually am ripping them off and the operating costs of the service they provide me is greater than what I have paid, they've decided that the value they derive from being able to boast a 100% data retention policy that results in consumer confidence is worth more. It's not kindness, it's investment.
I have it installed on an old netbook. I use Quasar or Exodus to stream movies and TV show episodes. It's pretty great. The Filipino channels don't seem to work though.

WRITING.TITLE: [Question] How to prevent iMessage/FaceTime activation?
WRITING.TEXT: Every once in a while (and every time my phone is restarted), iOS asks me to verify my icloud password. Whether I type it in or dismiss the prompt, it turns out this is iOS trying to activate my iMessage and FaceTime (and failing). The thing is, I never use iMessage or Facetime and have them disabled in my settings. Turning on iMessage and FaceTime triggers activation but it fails as well. I assume it fails because I'm using a refurbished/second hand/unlocked iPhone. Either way, I still get charged an activation fee by my carrier. Is there a way to permanently disable iMessage and FaceTime so I stopped getting charged? I'd switch carriers but every carrier in my area has that charge. On an iPhone 5S. iOS 9.3.3.
The activation always fails. I assume it's because I'm using an "unlocked" iPhone and apple isn't accepting my number which is from another network.

When you activate iMessage/FaceTime, the iPhone sends an SMS to Apple to verify your number. For many countries, it's free. But in some countries, Apple doesn't have a local number and so we are charged an international SMS fee. The problem with mine is that activation fails every time and every attempt results in a charge.
This guy plucks.

WRITING.TITLE: Any cordcutters here in the Philippines? What are your setups?
WRITING.TEXT: And is there a way to watch local channels online?
I've got an old laptop running Kodi hooked up to our dining room TV. It also doubles as a Debian server.

WRITING.TITLE: This installation wizard works in mysterious ways.
Your 2017 calendar can be reused in 2023.

WRITING.TEXT: Hijacking the top comment to expound on how Erap does it. In the Manila city hall, there's this cardboard box with a lid in front of Erap's office where the clerks would dump cash received as bribes from businesses based in Manila in exchange for favors, speedy bureaucracy, tax avoidance, etc. To buy their loyalty, the clerks are allowed to skim off the top of any bribes they receive. At the end of the day, Erap takes this box and goes to one of his regular casinos and gambles away all that cash while indulging himself. The cash of course ends up going back to him after the casino takes their own cut for laundering the money.

WRITING.TITLE: 7 years ago, NU 107, a modern rock radio station was taken off the air. A crowd gathered in front of the studio to watch their final signing off.

WRITING.TEXT: The Philippines.
"Bata din, meron." One day, the police set up a desk on the overpass and the bugaws disappeared for a while. Then the police stopped using the desk and the bugaws started sitting there.

My parents' experience: they were around 12 years old when Martial Law was declared and around 26 when Marcos was ousted. They didn't join any activist movements or communist organizations. Basically, kept their head down which was very easy to do. Both came from middle class families, got jobs right out of college working for the national airline which never saw a profit but the employees were well compensated. They made a lot of money and were able to use it to support a family. Their opinion of Marcos is that he did a good job keeping the nation in "order". The communists brought the violence upon themselves. They believe that Marcos did steal a lot of public money and squandered it. They witnessed it firsthand as employees of the national airline which the Marcoses used as their personal airline jet setting around the world. Entire sections of a 747 would be cordoned off for Imelda's dresses and shopping. They were fond of music and singing and would bring an entire rondalla (string ensemble) with them on the plane. The Marcoses would tip the crew in dollars. My parents agree the Philippines could be in a better place if Marcos didn't plunder the nation's wealth but they don't feel too bad about it because they had good jobs thanks to Marcos and experienced upward social mobility. My mom is a Duterte supporter and is in favor of martial law/strong state to keep the streets safer for her children. A professor at my university's experience: He's a few years older than my parents. Was attending college when Martial Law was declared in 1972. Participated in student activism leading up to it and during. Personally knew victims of kidnappings and assassinations. Biggest targets were student leaders and journalists. Militarized police would storm the campus. Curfew was in effect and anyone outside at night would be accosted by the MetroCom. Bags would be searched and anyone possessing anti government propaganda like flyers or newspapers with stories critical of the government were arrested and interrogated. Even having long hair as a male will put you under suspicion. Writ of habeas corpus was suspended and so detainees would be kept indefinitely without family members knowing their whereabouts. Some would be released without harm, some would return after being tortured. Electric shock to genitals, fingernails pulled out, rape, stab wounds. Some would be found much later dead and wrapped in garbage bags on the side of the road. The act was called "salvage". Some have yet to be found, we call them "desaparecido". Other targeted activists would be gunned down in the city or in their cars. My professor didn't join the communists that took up arms. He continued to write privately/secretly.
Martin Nievera is very kind to Flight Attendants and would give everyone a signed copy of whatever his latest album is every time he flies.
